title: 114_hr4943
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Tax and Investment Reform Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the unique relationship between the United States and Indian tribes, acknowledging tribes' authority to provide programs and services, develop economies, and maintain infrastructure on reservation lands. Federal laws and treaties affirm tribes as governments with the power to tax, issue bonds, and receive tax exemptions. Tax parity for tribal governments aligns with their sovereignty, addressing historic capital access challenges. Indian tribes face challenges in accessing capital for infrastructure and job creation, hindered by statutory restrictions on governance. They are sometimes excluded from key provisions in the Internal Revenue Code, leading to unfair tax treatment. Congress has the authority to regulate commerce with tribes, aiming to promote tribal self-governance and affirm the government-to-government relationship. Indian tribes are treated as states with respect to bond issuance. Indian tribal governments are subject to special rules for tax-exempt bonds, with the Secretary of the Treasury establishing a national bond volume cap based on tribal population estimates. The cap is then allocated among tribal governments seeking an allocation in a particular year. The amendment repeals certain requirements for Indian tribal governments regarding tax-exempt bonds, with new regulations prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury. The effective date applies to obligations issued in specific calendar years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Treatment of pension and employee benefit plans maintained by tribal governments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes and updating the definition of governmental plan to encompass plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes and updating the definition of governmental plan to encompass plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities. This includes provisions for domestic relations orders, exempt governmental deferred compensation plans, and grandfathering certain deferred compensation plans for tribal governments. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities owned or controlled by them. This expands the definition of governmental plans to encompass Indian tribal entities under Federal, State, or tribal law. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities owned or controlled by them, expanding the definition of governmental plans to encompass Indian tribal entities under Federal, State, or tribal law. Amendments include inserting "or tribal" after "State" in Section 206(d)(3)(B)(ii)(II) and adding a new paragraph in Section 4021(b) to cover plans established by Indian tribal governments or related entities. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities owned or controlled by them. The amendments made by this section shall apply to years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. Tribal foundations and charities treated like charities funded and controlled by governmental funders and sponsors. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include Indian tribal governments, agencies, and entities owned or controlled by them for tax purposes. These changes apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. IMPROVING TRIBAL CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES' ACCESS TO FEDERAL SERVICES. Improving tribal child support enforcement agencies' access to federal services by amending the Social Security Act to include Indian tribes and tribal organizations eligible for grants under specific sections. This also extends the applicability of collecting past-due child support from federal tax refunds to these tribes and organizations. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows Indian tribes and tribal organizations to be included as States for the purpose of collecting past-due child support from federal tax refunds. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code recognizes Indian tribal governments for determining special needs in the adoption credit. Effective for taxable years after enactment of the Act.
